column4: I've been trying to install cnet (a network simulator), but every time I try to run make, I get the same error: warning: cast from pointer to integer of different size. What should I look for in changing the default int size to match the one on my 64-bit machine?
good luck with that
its probably not 64bit clean
The way it's set up, it treats all warning as errors and fails to compile.
its probably not really a warning for a 64bit machine
I've not got a 64-bit version of Ubuntu installed.
an int and a pointer are different sizes on 64bit systems
oh i see
so you are running ubuntu i386 then?
How can I check that? I'm actually not 100%.
assuming you are running the 32bit verison of Ubuntu then removing the -werror from the compiler options should let it compile
you are using the 64bit version
Okay, I see.
so you can't make that code work as is, because its not written properly and won't work on 64bit
Any way to force it to run in 32-bit mode, or run a 32-bit emulator on my machine?
not easily
I've got an install of Ubuntu on a vmWare machine on Windows. Do you think it would work there?
you could setup vmware or something like that to run a 32bit version of Ubuntu
hivemind.
yes that might work, the code is buggy though in general so it might have other issues
What code is buggy in general?
casting int to pointer is a bad thing to do and shows that the person who wrote the code didn't know what they were doing
